title: Trotting Park Baseball Field Lead Levels Triple State Cap | Falmouth News | capenews.net
text:
The risk assessment report for the John L. Neill youth baseball complex is in. Analysis of the soils beneath the three fields found several toxins, including arsenic, antimony, zinc and polychlorinated bicarbonates (PCBs). But the biggest concern, the company said, is the lead that was detected.
The report was released to the Enterprise yesterday at 4:08 PM.
In one of the fiends—Field 1, which is the northernmost field at the site—lead concentrations three times those deemed acceptable by the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) were found within the first six inches of topsoil. DEP’s limit for lead is 200 parts per million; some soil samples taken from Field 1 found 600 ppm.
The fields, located off Gifford Street in Trotting Park, were built on top of an old town dump.
In September, the town was first alerted to potentially dangerous materials in the soil. In early January, the town closed the baseball complex after learning that the health threat was real.
“This concentration of lead detected in topsoil on Field 1 could pose an unacceptable risk to young children if repeated contact with soil beneath the existing turf was allowed,” the report’s summary reads.
The testing company, Arcadis, recommended that Field 1 remain closed for use and that the town install a “geotextile membrane,” or fabric covering, over the field and cover that with two to three feet of soil before it can be safe for baseball again.
Contaminants, including lead, were also found in the topsoil of the other two fields, but to a lesser extent, the report states.
Samples from Field 2 topped out at 190 ppm of lead, and Field 3 peaked at 45 ppm. That means two of the three baseball fields ”do not pose a risk to health for children contacting lead in topsoil on these fields,” the report states.
But deeper soil samples found much higher concentrations of contaminants beneath all three fields.
Between six inches and five feet deep in the soil, Field 2 exceeds state lead limits by 185 percent, and Field 3 by 25 percent.
Arcadis stated that while these deeper contaminants do not pose an immediate threat, they could be troublesome over the long-term.
The company said the town could allow play to resume on Fields 1 and 2 for the next year, as long as the topsoil is tested before play starts in the spring and periodically throughout the playing season. Next year, though, the town may have to look into adding more topsoil.
Besides lead, other landfill waste materials—like glass—were also found on the walking paths, particularly between Fields 1 and 2. Those materials ”could pose a safety risk under current conditions and should be addressed to mitigate risks from physical hazards.”
Arcadis recommended the town temporarily cover the paths with another “geotextile material” and add a soil covering.
The report also states that there is no imminent hazard to the surrounding environment.
The full report is 80 pages long, though Arcadis wrote that the information is not necessarily final.
“Additional investigation into the nature and extent of the landfill material underlying this area is ongoing and being managed in accordance with the [Massachusetts Contingency Plan],” the report states.
“These investigation activities include a geophysical study and additional soil borings to determine the extent of the landfill, and groundwater assessment to determine groundwater flow direction and groundwater quality.”
Town Manager Michael Renshaw was not immediately available for comment.
The select board is scheduled to discuss the report at its meeting Monday, February 24.
